Representations of partially ordered abelian groups

Feb 8, 2020

There is an equivalence due to Simpson stating that filtered vector spaces are equivalent to quasicoherent sheaves over . We talked about it in this post. There’s a generalization of this result which I’m currently in the process of writing up, which states the following. Let be a partially ordered abelian group (one could also do this with monoids), and let (resp. ) denote associated the monoid (resp. group) object in (flat) spectral schemes. There’s a coaction of on . The statement is then that there’s a (symmetric monoidal) equivalence between and the category of -equivariant quasicoherent sheaves on . We’ll denote by .

If , for instance, then this is the spectral version of Simpson’s equivalence.

The proof proceeds as follows. First, if is a discrete abelian group, then , where . This is quite straightforward to prove, once you recognize that . To get the desired equivalence between and , you just have to show that the functor is comonadic. This can be done by an application of Barr-Beck-Lurie.

OK, so how do you get up to ? There is a canonical map , where is the group regarded as a discrete space (i.e., forget the poset structure). This induces a functor , and it admits a left adjoint (which is given by left Kan extension along ). The functor is monadic. Indeed, it is conservative, and so by Barr-Beck-Lurie, it suffices to show that preserves geometric realizations. In fact, it preserves all colimits, because it also admits a right adjoint , which is given by right Kan extending along .

We claim that the image of the unit under is . Indeed, the tensor product in comes from Day convolution, and hence for , it is given by

As such, is given by

This is .

We’ve now established that is monadic. There are now two steps left. First, show that is monadic — this is easy, and follows from the fact that is affine. Therefore, is equivalent to . To finish, we therefore just need to show that as objects of .

Let , and let and . Then the functor

sends a quasicoherent sheaf to its underlying spectrum (aka global sections). But

so at least the underlying spectra of and are equivalent. Showing that they’re equivalent as objects of is now easy, because the action of on was defined via the coaction of on (which has nothing to do with the poset structure).
